div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7360] ALEXANDRIA, SATURDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1905. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged, as if the voyage were commending at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibralter, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Malls arrive Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
The Sea Fares are:-
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: COUP D'ETAT IN RUSSIA. GRAVE EVENTS AT TZARSKOE SELO. THE END AT HAND FINANCIAL PANIC. (Gazette's Special Service)

div.p: Things in Russia are undoubtedly going from bad to worse. There are rumours to-day that a great coup d’etat has taken place at St. Petersburg, and large numbers of Cossacks are said to be assembling in the Capital.
A great run on the savings banks through- out the country is taking place, and there exists a general financial panic.

Reuter's Agency learns from St. Petersburg that the attitude of the Government is consi- dered as suicidal, playing into the hands of the revolutionaries. Financial and commercial circles are aghast. There was a further heavy drop in prices both at St. Petersburg and at Moscow yesterday. It is openly declared in the Bourse and elsewhere that the days of the present regime are numbered.
(Reuter)

When the garrison of Fort Peter and Paul assembled for roll call, the artillery demanded the immediate release of the electrical students arrested on the 29th November. This demand was transmitted to the Commandant of the fortress, who complied.

It is officially confirmed that the loyal troops have captured the barracks occupied by the mutineers at Sevastopol. 2,000 of these with quick-firing guns have surrendered. The cruiser Otchakoff is gutted, but is still floating. The town is not damaged.

A number of Guardsmen have been arrested at Tzarskoe Selo for presenting demands ob- jecting to being obliged to act as police. It is reported that the mutineers at Sevastopol have regained the upper hand.
(Reuter)

It is rumoured that a Grand Duke partici- pated in a plot against the Tsar. There are some indications of conspiracy of the officers of the Guards, but it is impossible to say defi- nitely whether any Grand Duke participated. Officials, however, admit the reports of grave events at Tzarskoe Selo.
It is understood that the whole Cossack forces of the Empire will be mobilised.
(Reuter)
Martial law has been abolished in Poland.
(Reuter)
Martial law in Poland has been removed.
(Havas)
It is believed that to-day the Cabinet decid- ed upon resigning without dissolving.
It is understood that Mr. Balfour will see the King early next week, The Radical papers now intimate that Sir Henry Campbell-Banner- man is prepared to accept office if the King desires him so to do.
(Reuter)
The Algesiras conference has been put off till January.
(Havas)
The Assize Court has acquitted the prisoners accused of the attempt made on King Alfonso's life on May 31.
(Havas)
M. Jaluzot will appear before the Correc- tional Court on the 28th inst.
(Havas)

div.head: JOSEPH COMAS.
div.p: TECHNICAL ENGINEER.

Surveyor and Contractor in shipping. Takes charge of Engineers and Boilers. Undertakes repairs of same, guaranteeing success. First class references. Address: Rue el Warsha, Maison Gabriel, Alexandria.

div.head: Ghezireh Palace Hotel,
div.p: This hotel will open on Sunday, 10th inst.

div.head: The Mahmal Guard.
div.p: The Ministry of War has decided to send the Redif whose term of military service will expire in January next, to act as the guard of the Mahmal.

div.head: H.M.S. Carnarvon.
div.p: On leaving Alexandria next week the Car- narvon is expected to go to Patras, Platraes, and Corfu, returning to Malta (whence she came) on the 22nd inst.

div.head: Oxyrynchus.
div.p: recommence Messrs. Grenfell and Hunt, who have been staying at the Hotel du Nil, Cairo, are shortly proceeding to the Fayoum to recommence their excavations at Oxyrynchus.

div.head: Suex Canal.
div.p: Fifteen vessels passed through the canal on the 28th and 29th ult., of which 8 were British, 4 German, 2 Dutch, 1 Austrian. The total amount received in dues from the 1st to the 29th November was frs. 9,333,997.14

div.head: Minet el Kamh Court.
div.p: A correspondent writes to complain of the disgraceful state of the Native Court of justice at Minet el Kamh. The building is old and dilapidated and surrounded by malodorous birkets and native huts of the lowest descrip- tion.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: From the 1st of January to the 30th of November 985,669 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. Wales sent 531,639, Newcastle 221,413, Scotland 118,203, Yorkshire 74,373 and other places 40,041 tons. During the corresponding period of last year 979,309 tons were received.

div.head: Provincial Anglican Services.
div.p: To-morrow, the first Sunday in Advent, there will be a Litany and High Communion at 11 a.m. at Mansourah and Evensong at 6.30 p.m. at Tantah. The complete list of Anglican services at Mansourah and Tantah during the month will be published in an ap- proaching issue.

div.head: A.L.M. & D.S.
div.p: We are asked to remind our readers of the lecture to be given at St. Andrew's High School on Monday next by Dr. Ruffer, C.M.G., on "The Desert of Sinai." The lecture will com- mence at 9 p.m. and will be illustrated by about 60 lantern slides. A large gathering is expect- ed, as many tickets have been disposed of.

div.head: New Khedivial Hotel.
div.p: This evening the new "five o'clock tea" will be inaugurated at the New Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria. The Tsigane band will play a charming selection of airs. This combination of tea and music, which promises to be a favourite fixture with Alexandrian Society, may be enjoyed daily during the winter season.

div.head: Cairo Tramway Co.
div.p: Eighty new cars are arriving in Egypt before next February for the Cairo Tramway Com- pany. Each car is fitted with a first-class compartment and a harem. Next week the company will begin the new line from the Cairo station to Zaptieh. The extension of the Boulac line to the railway workshops will also soon be begun.
H.H. the Khedive has been graciously pleas- ed to confer the rank of Lewa on Captain McMurdo, Director of the Slave Trade Repres- sion Department.

Count de Vanvineux, French Commissioner to the Caisse de la Dette, is expected to return in a few days to Cairo. The Count passed the summer at Invernsch in Scotland and has been staying in France since the middle of Sep- tember.
Count Antoine de Zogheb returns on the 18th inst. The Countess de Zogheb will not return to Cairo till early in January.
The Rev. John Watson (so well known under his nom de plume Ian Maclaren) and Mrs. Watson left Cairo yesterday morning, and intend to make a short stay in Sicily.
The Hon. F.G. Morgan, American Vice- Consul-General, and Mrs. Morgan are spending a few days at Mena House.
Lieut. Col. Ludlew, A.S.C., late D.A.A. and Q.M.G. at Alexandria, as assumed duty at Cairo as officer commanding the A.S.C. in Egypt.
M. Anders, dragoman of the German Diploma- tic Agency, left Alexandria yesterday for Mossoul (Mesopotamia), where he will open a new consulate.

The following passengers left Cairo on the 1st inst. by P.S. Hatasoo for the Nile trip:- Mr. J. Sonneborn, Mr. A. Fischinger, Mr. A.P. Stewart, Baron Dr. Anton Koblitz, Dr. Anton Janiczek, Miss A. M. Harsant, Mr. C.B. Harsant, Mr. P.O. Cassidy, Mr. R.D. Bingham, Mr. J.E. Bingham, Mr. J.L. Low, Mrs. Low, Mr. M. Sanchioni, MMr. B.T. Hammond, Mr. D.F. Dunn, Miss Nanfan Barnes, Miss Baird, Miss McKellar, Mrs. F.B. Wilde, Miss K. Wilde, Mr. Paul Duflot, Mrs. P. Duflot, Miss C. Duflot, Miss S. Duflot, Mr. Charles Labelle, Mrs. Charles Labelle, Comte d'Acqui.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES MEETING OF CREDITORS.
div.p: The meeting of the creditors of the Societe des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte, postponed from Thursday last, took place yesterday at the Mixed Courts, Cairo. At 3.15 p.m. Judge Tuck opened the proceedings by stating that he had received communications from cultivators in Upper Egypt hoping that the Sucreries Co. would continue to exist. He then read a letter which he had received from the directors of the Sucreries Company, who criticized the last report of the experts on two grounds-firstly, the though it had been agreed that a copy of the report prepared by Sir William Willcocks, Fourneron Bey, and Professor Sampaolo should be put into the hands of the board of directors 48 hours before the meeting of creditors convoked under the concordat preventif, the members of the board were not, as a matter of fact, supplied therewith, and were in consequence compelled to hear its criticisms in silence, unable to offer a prepared defence. The criticisms of the ex- perts who had two months' time to prepare their attack reached the public, through the medium of the press, unbalance by the defence which the directors would otherwise have been in a position to offer. Secondly, they protested against the excessive animus that marked the criticisms passed on the administration of the company by the three experts.

Judge Tuck, in reply, stated that on the first occasion when the report was to be read, the three experts found themselves unable to complete it in time to deliver a copy to the representatives of the Sucreries Company forty- eight hours before the meeting of the creditors took place. The legal representative of the company was warned but demanded no post- ponement. No engagement was entered into the delivery of a copy forty-eight hours in advance on any later occasion.

The Judge then called upon M. Zigliara, the clerk of the court, to read the correspon- dence that had arisen re the letter written by Me. Fatica and addressed to Judge Tuck on the subject of the Ibrahimieh Ploughing Company. The correspondence consisted of the experts' answer to Me. Fatica and a com- munication from the board of the Sucreries Co. on the same subject, with a covering letter from the Hon. A.J. Davey.

The correspondence having been read Me. Carton de Wiart mentioned the results of the Sucreries shareholders' extraordinary general meeting of the Saturday last and stated that certain further delays in the acceptance of the proposals made under the concordat pre- ventif were inevitable owing to the appoint- ment of MM. Letort and Cozziks, who were to study these proposals and watch the nego- tiations connected therewith on behalf of the shareholders at Paris and at Cairo respectively. These gentlemen had not been as of yet able to come to an entirely satisfactory arrangement with one another and the board would not be able to bring its proposals before the court till Monday or Tuesday next. He in conse- quence asked for a postponement during which the verification of the claims of the creditors could be made or at least begun, and the meeting was in consequence adjourned till Tuesday and Saturday next.

div.head: MACHELL-GLEICHEN MARRIAGE.
div.p: The marriage of Countess Valda Gliechen and Mr. Machell will be quite a small affair and the King and Queen are to be present with other members of the family. As the apartments of Princess Victor Hohenlobe- Langenburg are so small, many of the Countess Valda's friends will be invited to a reception which is to take place in the Armoury of St. James' Palace on the day before the wedding. Countess Valda's real names are Victoria Alice Leopoldine Ada Laura and she adopts the name of Valda from V.A.L. Ada.

Mr. Percy Wilfrid Machell is the son of the late Rev. Canon Machell and the Hon. Mrs. Machell, of York. On the death of his uncle, the late Captain Machell, he succeeded to the old family property of Crackenthorpe, in West- moreland, which was in the possession of his family at the time of the Domesday Book Deeds and family records show direct descent as Lord of Crackenthorpe from 1246 until the property sold in 1786 by Lancelot Machell, elder brother of Colonel Machell, Mr. Machell's great-grandfather, who lost his arm at the battle of Bunker's Hill. Crackenthorpe was repurchased by the late Captain Machell from Lord Lonsdale in 1877. Mr. Machell's mother, who is still living and is resident in York, is a sister of the 8th Lord Middleton of Bridshail, Yorkshire. Born on the 5th December, 1862, Mr. Machell was educated at Clifton and Sand- hurst. He joined the 56th Regiment as lieu- tenant on 10th May, 1882, was promoted captain in October, 1888, temporary major in the Army, 1893, and retired (Reserve of Officers) in 1896. He served with the Mile expedition- ary Force in 1884-85, when he received medal with clasp and Bronze Star, and joined the Egyptian Army in 1886. He was present at the capture of Khormouan, 1888, and received the 4th class Osmanieh. He also took part in the operations round Suakin and the action of Femaizeh 1888 (horse shot), Sudan 1888-90-91, actin of Toski as Brigade Major No. 2 column, capture of Toffar (clasp on bronze star and 4th class Medjidieh). He commanded the 12th Sudanese Battalion, 1891-95, was Inspector General, Egyptian Coastguards, 1896, and was appointed Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, 1898. He received the Grand Cordon of the Medjidieh in 1902.

div.head: CAIRO IMPROVEMENTS. THE GHEZIREH BRIDGE.
div.p: Another new bridge is to be built across the Nile, the Government having decided on the construction of a magnificent structure to unite Boulac and Ghezireh. The work will be taken in hand shortly.

The new bridge will be twenty metres in width and will form a most convenient connect- ing link between the centre of Cairo and the fashionable new suburb of Ghezireh by the Boulac avenue. The Ghezireh quarter will thus soon form an integral portion of the Capital, especially as a double line of tramway is to be laid across the river. The Ghezireh end of the bridge will be about two metres to the north of the Ghezireh Palace Hotel and will divide the estate of the Egyptian Hotels Company in two parts.

It is obvious that with the universal tend- ency of all great cities-Alexandria being on of the very few exceptions to the general rule- to extend, so far as concerns their fashionable quarters, in a westerly direction, Ghezireh is inevitably destined to become the "Champs Elysees" of the Capital of Egypt. The only drawback to the development of Ghezireh has been its distance from the centre of the city, but this will be now entirely obviated by the new bridge, which will bring it in direct communica- tion with the centre of Cairo.

div.head: THE GHIZEH WASH-OUT.
div.p: A telegram received from the Traffic Mana- ger, State Railways, states that transhipment of passengers at Abon el Noumros will cease from to-day, and trains will pass directly to the south.

div.head: PORT SAID CONSULATE.
div.p: The King has been graciously pleased to appoint Donald Andreas Cameron, Esq., to be his Majesty's Consul-General at Port Said, with jurisdiction over all the coast-line east of Damietta Light to El-Arish, the Suez Maritime Canal, the banks of the Canal, including the towns of Ismailia and Suez.

div.head: VARIOUS CREDITS.
div.p: The sum of L.E. 25,000 is to be spent during the next financial year on the Ghizeh reformatory school, L.E. 20,000 on the enlargement of the Abbassieh madhouse. Another credit of L.E. 10,000 is to be opened for the Technical School at Cairo and L.E. 40,000 will be expended on the new secondary schools which are to be built at Ghizeh and Abbassieh.

div.head: CAIRO WATER COMPANY.
div.p: The inauguration of the new artesian wells constructed by the Cairo Water Company at Rod el-Farag will take place about the end of December or the beginning of January, in the presence of H.H. the Khedive.
The company's new works at Boulac will be completed in a few months, when the Nile Cold Storage Company will transfer their machinery thereto.

div.head: GLOBE-TROTTER AT LUXOR. (From our Correspondent)
div.p: A.W. Crawford, the globe-trotter, has pass- ed by this town on his way to Khartoum and Abyssinia. In the latter place, he does not expect "much fun," as he expressed it.

This typical young American is well equip- ped for his tour, physically and mentally; for I see in him, a keen observer, a reasoning thinker and an excellent writer, besides that apparent coolness that characterises his nation. He will reach the United States, landing at San Francisco, in April, 1907. I certainly do wish him a happy and an interesting world- around trip.

div.head: NEW ROUTE TO ABYSSINIA.
div.p: It is stated by the "Temps" that a company has been formed in London to pen up com- mercially the river Jube, which separates British East Africa from Italian Somali land. A flotilla of tugs and barges is said to be in process of construction for the navigation of the river. The company is credited with the intention of linking the extreme point reached by their boat service with the Abyssinian capital by means of a caravan route which will compete with the Harrar Railway.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID. (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
div.p: On the evening of Wednesday a grand concert was given by the band from an Austrian first-class cruiser in the little garden adjoining the Eastern Exchange, in aid of the Austrian Benevolent Society of Port Said. The garden was magnificently decorated with flags of all nations. The band played 10 very select pieces and were twice encored. It is hoped that the society will be able to make a few homes com- fortable with the proceeds of this concert.
A big ball will be given at the Eastern Exchange on the 16th February in aid of our new Sporting Club.

div.head: THE SAMANOUD AFFAIR. TRUE VERSION OF INCIDENT.
div.p: As certain exaggerated statements have been published with regard to a disturbance at Sa- manoud, Gharbieh province, we are glad to be able to give the true account of the concurrence there, which we have from official sources.

It appears that on the morning of the 27th November, a telegram from a number of Copts and Europeans reached the moudirieh head- quarters, stating that a number of Muslims had insulted the Christian religion by holding a mock funeral, imitating the officiating priest and cross-bearer.

On enquiries being made it proved that seven men of the lowest class had insulted both Christian and Muslim religions. On the morn- ing of the 27th they entered the El Adawi- mosque, interrupted prayers, and created a great disturbance. After leaving the mosque they indulged in a travesty of a Christian funeral, and having insulted both religions found themselves pursued by the police.
five have been arrested and have confessed their guilt. The remaining members of the gang are the object of careful search.

div.head: BRITISH CONCULAR COURT. IMPORTANT DECISION.
div.p: The appeal of the defendant in the case of Major Nicol, of the Rifle Brigade, against a local firm of carriers and forwarding agents came on for bearing yesterday morning before Judge Cator at the British Consular Court in Cairo. Major Nicol had in the first in- stance recovered £131 damages in the lower Court for loss of goods pilfered from luggage which he had entrusted to the defendant firm to forward from Cairo to London. Against this decision the defendants appealed, but the judge dismissed the appeal with costs.

The case was made interesting by several points of public interest, amongst which was the fact that the plaintiff had insured his luggage against marine risks only and for a sum inferior to the amount of his claim.
Mr. Frederick Leveneaux, of Alexandria, appeared for Major Nicol and Dr. Sciortino, LLD., for the defendant firm of carriers.

div.head: BELGIAN CONSULATE.
div.p: The Belgian Government has appointed Mr. Rabyns de Schneidaner Acting Consul at Alex- andria. This gentleman was formerly at the Belgian Consulate at Smyrns. He is a consul "de carriere." Hitherto the Belgian Consulate at Alexandria has been occupied by an un- professional consul.

div.head: UM RUS OPERATIONS.
div.p: The progress report No. 58, for half-month ending Oct. 31st, gives the following par- ticulars of operations:

550 ft cross-out was advanced 9 ft, to a total distance of 70 ft. At 67 ft in a branch of quartz was out 4 ins wide, assaying 1 oz 3 dwts 5 grs per ton. 450-ft level north-east was extended 15 ft to a total of 107 ft, passing through dykes 4 and 5. Quartz at junction with dykes was 12 ins wide, assaying 3 dwts 22 grs per ton. 450-ft level south-west was driven 10 ft, total length 115 ft; the quartz averaged 11 ins wide, worth 4 dwts 3 grs per ton. 450-ft main winze was deepened 10 ft, making a total depth of 91 ft. Over this distance the vein average 20 ins wide and 16 dwts 3 grs per ton in value. 350-ft level north-east was advanced 4 ft, to a distance of 302 ft; suspended, Cross-out south-east at 300 ft was driven 10 ft; no discovery. 350 ft No. 2 winze north-east was deepened 10 ft, total depth 68 ft; in dyke No. 3 350 ft level south-west was extended 11 ft 6 ins to a total distance of 357 ft 6 ins. Vein averaged 19 ins wide and dwts per ton in value. 350-ft No. 2 winze south-west was sunk 10 ft, to a depth of 74 ft; in dyke No. 8. 245-ft level north-east was advanced 14 ft, total distance 251 ft. Quartz averaged 8 ins assay- ing a trace. In two stopes below this level the quartz is 21 ins wide, worth 1 oz 1 dwt 6 grs per ton. 245 south-west level was ad- vanced 5 ft, total distance 395 ft. Quartz, 8 ins wide, assayed a trace of gold per ton. In a stope below this level the quartz, 24 ins wide, is worth 7 dwts per ton. 245 No. 3 wings south-west was deepened 14 ft, total depth 115 ft. Quartz 12 ins wide, assayed a trace. Will shortly make connection with No. 3 level. Western shaft was sunk 4 ft; in granite. Total depth 252 ft. 75-ft level south-west was advanced 4ft to a distance of 147 ft. Quartz, 11 ins wide, assayed 7 dwts 13 grs per ton.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY. FOOTBALL
div.p: The meeting of the Railway Institute F.C. and F. Co. of the K.R.R. on Tuesday, proved to be a capital game. The slight rain which fell in the forenoon had no effect on the ground,- if anything it improved it. The railway men's full team turned out to opposed their antagon- ists. From the very start off and all through the first half the home team were the superior XI., and they were continually attacking the visitors' custodian. The consequence was, that when the first half terminated, the railway men had 5 goals to their credit. In the second half F. Co. struggled with the desperate energy, and by the 'cute understanding of the left wing pair, managed to score a couple of goals. Thus the Railway Institute were left the victors by 5 goals to 2. Mr. Allport was the referee.

div.head: SOCIETE KHEDIVIALE DE GEOGRAPHIE
div.p: Le commandant C. Lemaire, du 2e regiment d'artilerie belge, vient d'envoyer a la Societe Khedivial de Geographie la collection de ses nombreuses publications, relative a ses explo- rations au Congo. Ce brillant officer se dis- tingne par son activite et les services qu'il a deja rendu a la science le mettent au premier rang des voyageurs acientifiques. Parmi les travaux qu'il nous a envoyes nons devons signaler la magistrale "Mission Scientifique du Katanga" en 16 memoires, splendide publica- tion in 4, enrichie de magnifiques dessins, photographies et aquarelles, qui permettent de suivre des yeux l'explorateur dans ses pere- grinations. Les memoires, ou volumes, con- tiennent le journal de route et les resultats des observations astronomiques, magnetiques et altimetriques effectnees sur les territoires qu'il a traverses du 4 Aout 1898 au 2 Septembre 1900.
L'ouvrage est accompagne d'une grande carte du Katangra au 100,000eme et de 30 feuilles (des 130 qui composent la meme Carte) au 50.000eme.
Comme on le voit, il a'agit d'un travail fou- damental, honore d'une preface d'Elisee Reclus.

Le Commandant Lemaire, sera parmi nous, de retour du Congo, en Janvier et nous savons que sur les instances de la Societe et de ses amis, il a consenti a donner une conference au Caire sur ses voyages. Cette conference sera agremantee de projections.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTELS.
div.p: Nous publions d'antre part le prospectus relatif a l'emission publique des actions de "The National Hotels & Residence Company" dont la souscription sera ouverte a l'Anglo- Egyptian Bank les lundi 4 et Mardi 5 Decem- bre courant.

Nous avons deja eu l'occasion d'entretenir nos lecteurs de cette affaire, lors de l'inaugu- ration du "National Hotel" dont la nouvelle compagnie est devenue proprietaire; nous ne nous etendrons donc plus aur la description de cet etablissement.
Par contre, que'ques mots ne seront pas superflus au sujet du Grand Hotel et Casino d'Ain-Sofar, que la compagnie a egalement achete.

Ain-Sofar, situe dans la partie la plus belle et la plus saine du Liban a une altitude de 1,350 metre, est deja actuellement la ville- giature estivale de nombre d'Egyptians, et il est certain que bien des Europaens desireux de se reposer des fatigues de notre climat sesont heureux d'aller y respirer l'air frais et vivifiant de la montagne, plutot que de faire le voyage long et couteux d'Europe; Aiu-Aofar n'est en effet qu'a 24 heures de l'Egypte.

C'est an aurplus une fort heureuse ides qu'a la Societe d'exploiter en meme temps des Hotels en Egypt et en Syris, ce qui lui per- mettra avec un personnel a pierne superieur a celui qui serait necessaire a l'un des etalibes- ments, de mener de front les deux, vu qu'ils ne seront respentivement en pleine activite qu'en des saisons differentes.

L'emission de la "N. H. & R. C." nous paralt au demeurant ne pouvoir etre qu'un succes. Toutes les affaires d'hotels montes dans ce pays ont donne des resultats brillants, et leurs actions sont cotees actuellement pour la p'upart, a 250% de leur valeur nominale; pourquoi n'en serait-il pas de meme pour la "National" qui n'a pas pour seul but de cher- cher a creer des affaires nouvelles, mais offre a ses actionnaires d'importants etablissements en pleine exploitation.

div.head: BOURSE DU CAIRE
div.p: Caire, la ler Decembre
Le marche a ete certainement meilleur qu'on ne l'esperait.
Non seulement la baissa de Londres n'a pas ete suivie, mais il y a eu pendent un momnet un mouvement qui semblait etre le precurseur d'une reprise.

Ainsi la National Bank que l'Exchange cotait 25 a eu des acheteurs aux environs de 25 1/4 pour l'ancienne et 24 7/8 pour la nou- velle. C'est du reste a ce prix que la bourse de Londres a pratique aujourd'hui.
L'agricultural Bank a fait 9 3/16; elle cote 9 3/8 en Europe - c'est une smeliora- tions sensible.
Le Credit Foncier Egyptian demeure station- naire aux environs de 780 Frs. ; une avance rapide ne nous etonnerait pas, le cap de la liquidation ayant ete facilement franchi.
Le marche a ete bon pour les Egyptian Estates; les titres changent de main dans d'excellentes conditions pour les acheteurs; la premiere occasion servira la hanses.
Les Nungovich Hotels ont oscille entre 10 1/2 et 10 7/16; on les a reclames a terme mais les vendeurs monquent.
Les Baehler ontavance d'un huitienne environ et les Upper ont enragistre 5 3/16.
Le saison commence bien, les touristes ar- riveut plus tot que l'annee derniere; personne ne s'en plaindre.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (aujourd'hui a midi et demie)
Le marche est en general assex soutenu mais peu brillent comme affaires.

La Banque Nationale flechit a 24 3/4, la Ban- que d'Athenes a 136 1/2, la Banque d'Abyssinie a 7, la Delta Land a 2 3/16. l'Urbaine a 5, la Crown Brewery a 205, les Markets a 26/3, la Salt and Soda a 21/3, et l'Alexandria Water a 14 1/2.
Comme on le voit pas les chiffres ci-dessurs les petites valeuqs perdent de nouveau da terrain, a l'exception des Estates qui sont fereus a 1 3/8.
Eu hausse l'Obligation Foncier reown a 315 1/2. l'Agrisule a 9 7/38, la Cssa de ecoute a 210 1/2, les Bachles a 2 15/16, la Ramleh Rad- way a 6 15/16, et les Privilegiees Tramways a 155 1/2.
